questions.question: Who was Thiruvalluvar?
questions.answer: Thiruvalluvar was a great Tamil Saint-poet and textile weaver who lived more than two thousand years ago.

questions.question: What is 'Thirukkural'?
questions.answer: 'Thirukkural' is a book containing the teachings of Thiruvalluvar.

questions.question: What items did Thiruvalluvar weave and sell?
questions.answer: He wove beautiful fabrics and saris and sold them in the market.

questions.question: Describe the character of Thiruvalluvar as mentioned by people.
questions.answer: People said he never got angry, never used bad words, and never shouted at anyone.

questions.question: How did the rich young man spend his time?
questions.answer: He wasted most of his time roaming around with his friends and making fun of other people.

questions.question: What was the young man's challenge to himself?
questions.answer: The young man challenged himself to make Thiruvalluvar angry.

questions.question: What did the young man do when he first approached Thiruvalluvar?
questions.answer: He picked up a beautiful piece of fabric and asked how much it cost.

questions.question: What was the initial price of the fabric?
questions.answer: The initial price was eight coins.

questions.question: What did the young man do to the fabric to try and provoke the Saint?
questions.answer: He tore the fabric into two and eventually into rags.

questions.question: How did Thiruvalluvar respond when the fabric was torn into two?
questions.answer: He answered politely that the price for the piece was now four coins.

questions.question: Why was the youth 'taken aback' during the interaction?
questions.answer: He was taken aback because Thiruvalluvar did not get angry despite the fabric being torn.

questions.question: What was the price when the pieces were torn again and again?
questions.answer: The price was reduced to half every time: from eight to four, then two, and so on.

questions.question: What happened to the fabric at the end of the young man's actions?
questions.answer: The fabric was reduced to worthless rags.

questions.question: Why did Thiruvalluvar say the fabric had become worthless?
questions.answer: It became worthless because no one would be able to wear it anymore.

questions.question: What did the young man offer to pay at the end?
questions.answer: He offered to pay eight coins to the Saint.

questions.question: Why did Thiruvalluvar refuse the money?
questions.answer: He refused because the fabric was now of no use, and he would not take money for something worthless.

questions.question: Explain the role of the farmer in making the fabric.
questions.answer: The farmer grew cotton in his field, working for months through sun and rain, and picked cotton from each boll.

questions.question: What happens after the cotton is picked?
questions.answer: It is given for spinning, carded, and spun into long, uniform threads.

questions.question: How did the threads get their lovely colors?
questions.answer: The threads were dyed carefully to take on those colors.

questions.question: Who wove the threads together?
questions.answer: Thiruvalluvar and his wife wove the threads together.

questions.question: What did the weavers hope for while making the fabric?
questions.answer: They hoped that someday someone would like the fabric, wear it, and be happy.

questions.question: What did destroying the fabric represent to Thiruvalluvar?
questions.answer: It represented the destruction of all the love and labor that went into making it.

questions.question: Why can money not bring back the fabric?
questions.answer: Money can pay for the material, but it cannot bring back the months of hard work and care put in by many people.

questions.question: How did the young man feel after hearing Thiruvalluvar's explanation?
questions.answer: He felt really ashamed of himself and his heart was touched by the softly spoken words.

questions.question: What is the comparison made between life and the fabric?
questions.answer: Like the fabric, life can be destroyed by hasty, thoughtless actions, and once destroyed, it cannot be gotten back.

questions.question: What was the final result of Thiruvalluvar's words on the young man?
questions.answer: The young man's eyes were opened, and he decided to give up his idleness and bad habits.

questions.question: What does 'spinning' mean?
questions.answer: Spinning is the process of making yarn or thread out of cotton wool.

questions.question: Define 'carded' as used in the text.
questions.answer: Carded means cleaned and combed cotton to remove seeds.

questions.question: What does it mean to be 'rewarded' in the context of the story?
questions.answer: It means getting what one has worked for, such as seeing someone happy wearing the fabric.

questions.question: Why did Thiruvalluvar smile for the first time?
questions.answer: He smiled while refusing the money, perhaps seeing the young man's realization or maintaining his calm demeanor.

questions.question: Where did Thiruvalluvar sell his goods?
questions.answer: He sold them in the market.

questions.question: How many years ago did the Saint live?
questions.answer: He lived more than two thousand years ago.

questions.question: What kind of words did Thiruvalluvar use?
questions.answer: He used softly spoken words and never used bad words.

questions.question: What was the young man proud of?
questions.answer: He was proud of his riches.

questions.question: What is the central message of the story?
questions.answer: The message is to value the labor of others and to realize that thoughtless actions can destroy precious things like life and effort.

questions.question: What did the farmer have to endure to grow cotton?
questions.answer: The farmer had to work through sun and rain for months.

questions.question: Who helped Thiruvalluvar in weaving?
questions.answer: His wife helped him in weaving.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'opened the young man's eyes' mean?
questions.answer: It means he was made to realize the truth or understand his mistake.

questions.question: How did the Saint name the price of the fabric pieces?
questions.answer: He named them calmly and politely.

questions.question: Could the weaver weave another fabric?
questions.answer: Yes, Thiruvalluvar said he could weave another fabric, but life cannot be replaced.

questions.question: What does 'toiled' mean in the text?
questions.answer: Toiled means worked extremely hard.

questions.question: What did the young man's friends do?
questions.answer: They roamed around with him and often made fun of other people.

questions.question: Why didn't Thiruvalluvar name a price for the rags?
questions.answer: Because the rags were worthless and could not be used for anything.

questions.question: What are 'uniform threads'?
questions.answer: Threads that are consistent in thickness and quality throughout.

questions.question: What kind of tone did Thiruvalluvar use when the fabric became rags?
questions.answer: He used a quiet tone.

questions.question: How long did the farmer work?
questions.answer: The farmer worked for months.

questions.question: What was the youth's mental state when he tore the pieces again and again?
questions.answer: He became impatient and agitated.

questions.question: What does 'agitated' mean?
questions.answer: Agitated means feeling troubled, nervous, or excited.

questions.question: Did Thiruvalluvar ever shout?
questions.answer: No, people said he never shouted at anyone.

questions.question: What is the lesson about money in this story?
questions.answer: Money cannot compensate for the loss of hard work, love, and life's value.
